title: Weekend reads: Trying unsuccessfully to correct the scientific record; drug company funding and research
author: Author Ivan Oransky
description: There were lots of pieces about scientific misconduct, publishing, and related issues posted around the web this week, so without further ado:
cleaned_text: of pieces about scientific misconduct, publishing, and related issues posted around the web this week, so without further ado:](http://retractionwatch.files.wordpress.com/2013/11/books.jpg) - The News & Observer has a great [two-part](http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/01/18/3539211/ncsu-professor-becomes-convinced.html) [series](http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/01/19/3544566/in-a-notebook-at-nc-state-a-smoking.html)about a Stefan Franzen, a chemistry professor at North Carolina State University who has been trying unsuccessfully to correct the scientific record, including a paper in Science. (Here's a [2011 report on the case from Nature.)](http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110823/full/news.2011.497.html)The reporter, Joseph Neff, puts the series into context [here](http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/01/19/3544568/errors-and-fraud-multiply-in-science.html). [Pacific Standard](http://www.psmag.com/uncategorized/the-missus-marriage-gender-feminism-names-62460/)and [Slate](http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2014/01/17/another_reason_to_keep_your_name_when_getting_married_better_job_offers.html)have corrected pieces on what happens when women take their husbands' names because they both relied on [retracted research by Diederik Stapel](http://retractionwatch.com/2012/04/26/journal-retracts-two-stapel-papers-on-salesmen-and-on-women-who-change-their-names-when-they-marry/). - "It's not often that a journal will call attention to unreliable findings that it publishes..." But the [editor of Human Reproduction did](http://www.medpagetoday.com/Endocrinology/GeneralEndocrinology/43917). And the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism [may walk back a policy](http://www.medpagetoday.com/Endocrinology/Steroids/43861)under which they "would no longer publish work that used immunoassays to measure steroid levels for primary outcomes," following strong reader reaction. - Following our [coverage of a silent retraction in Cureus](http://retractionwatch.com/2014/01/22/journal-reveals-real-reason-for-retraction-of-paper-by-author-who-threatened-to-sue-retraction-watch/)of a paper by a researcher who has threatened to sue us, the journal explains [how it deals with retractions](http://blog.cureus.com/2014/01/24/how-cureus-deals-with-article-retractions/). - The Guardian details the [story of Nick Brown](http://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/jan/19/mathematics-of-happiness-debunked-nick-brown), the "British amateur who debunked the mathematics of happiness" and whose work [we covered in September](http://retractionwatch.com/2013/09/19/fredrickson-losada-positivity-ratio-paper-partially-withdrawn/). Narrative.ly [wrote about Brown in October](http://narrative.ly/pieces-of-mind/nick-brown-smelled-bull/). - Benjamin Schwessinger, a colleague of Pamela Ronald's, gives a [behind-the-scenes look](http://blushgreengrassatafridayafternoon.wordpress.com/2014/01/23/behind-the-scences-the-people-who-debunked-ax21/)at what led to the lab's [two retractions](http://retractionwatch.com/2014/01/14/following-up-pamela-ronald-publishes-updated-data-following-two-retractions/). - Julia Belluz [sits in on a class by John Ioannidis](http://www2.macleans.ca/2014/01/17/when-science-isnt-science-based-in-class-with-dr-john-ioannidis/), who has made a career out of showing how many studies don't hold up. Ioannidis also features prominently in a New York Times [essay on reproducibility](http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/21/science/new-truths-that-only-one-can-see.html?_r=0)by George Johnson. - The University of Queensland offered an [update](http://www.uq.edu.au/news/article/2014/01/uq-continues-second-phase-of-research-misconduct-investigation)on their investigation of [Levon Khachigian](http://retractionwatch.com/category/by-author/levon-khachigian/), who has had four papers retracted [Bruce Murdoch](http://retractionwatch.com/2013/09/03/aussie-university-asks-for-retraction-investigates-former-neurology-researcher-for-fraud/), who has had [one paper retracted](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ene.12276/abstract). - Here's what MIT was [teaching about the responsible conduct of research](http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/health-sciences-and-technology/hst-502-survival-skills-for-researchers-the-responsible-conduct-of-research-spring-2003/index.htm)before fraudster [Luk Van Parijs](http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110728/full/news.2011.437.html)joined the faculty. - "Should journals [stop publishing research funded by the drug industry](http://www.bmj.com/content/348/bmj.g171)?" - At the Scholarly Kitchen, Kent Anderson says an analysis of advertising in medical journals — which we highlighted in a [recent Weekend Reads](http://retractionwatch.com/2014/01/11/weekend-reads-waste-in-research-a-praise-worthy-swift-correction-in-nejm-and-more/)— is " [fatally flawed](http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2014/01/17/not-as-advertised-why-an-academic-analysis-of-medical-journal-advertising-is-fatally-flawed/)." - For some scientists, it's unclear [what's new](http://www.the-scientist.com//?articles.view/articleNo/38919/title/Not-So-New-/)about a recently published paper on "quilt plots." - JAMA has posted an [oral history of the evidence-based medicine movement.](http://ebm.jamanetwork.com/) - "I need to stay alert to one of the most corrupting forms of temptation, stopping myself from selecting evidence for no better reason than that it [confirms my prior thinking](http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/comment/columnists/serendipitous-scholarship/2010433.article)." - Genome Web [adds a lot of detail](http://www.genomeweb.com/pcrsample-prep/second-group-ids-contaminated-qiagen-sample-prep-products-casts-doubt-novel-viru)(sub req'd) to the story of a former NIH researcher who falsified images that [we covered last month](http://retractionwatch.com/2013/12/29/former-nih-scientist-falsified-images-ori/). - What scientific ideas are ready for retirement? That's the [question Edge asked](http://edge.org/annual-question/what-scientific-idea-is-ready-for-retirement). Tabitha Powledge has a [roundup](http://blogs.plos.org/onscienceblogs/2014/01/24/scientific-ideas-garbage-dump/). - As part of its [Supplement Shell Game series](http://www.usatoday.com/topic/a6a2541c-0b71-46bf-81a5-c3d21ba55b2d/supplement-shell-game%20/), USA Today finds that one of the main authors of a study supposedly showing the value of Craze is a [doctor who has been disciplined in two states](http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/01/23/driven-sports-sponsors-safety-study-of-craze-supplement/4720747/). - Here's a [groaner of a comic about plagiarism](http://pic.twitter.com/r4v5xeemDA), featuring DNA.
